name: Tom's Library
bio: A running list of books I've read...

books.title: Simulation and its discontents
books.author: Sherry Turkle
books.notes: An excellent short adventure through the ways computers simulate the world around us and how that changes our perception of the world and computers. Especially relevant for today's world of AI.

books.title: The Lathe of Heaven
books.author: Ursula K. Le Guin
books.notes: Excellent! Dreams as simulations. The perils of agency. A vivid description of a wonderful unique premise. This could easily have gone off the rails but Ursula is a master and this was amazing. The ending at first gave me pause but I think I've come to terms with it and embrace the taoist reading.. Beautiful writing.

books.title: The maniac
books.author: Benjam√≠n Labatut
books.notes: Super engrossing. I had just watched the AlphaGo documentary and AI is of course 100% of the discourse and so this felt very timely but also timeless. I slightly preferred When We Cease to Understand the World but this was a close second. Excellent.

books.title: How the light gets in
books.author: Pat Schneider
books.notes: Wow. Thank you Brian for this amazing book. Poetry, writing, spirituality, self publishing and so much more. This was part autobiography, part writing manual and part manifesto for creativity and believing in yourself. Magical. Highly recommended.

books.title: When We Cease to Understand the World
books.author: Benjam√≠n Labatut
books.notes: One of my all time faves. What an astonishing book. Mathematics, insanity, creativity. Highly recommended.

books.title: Moonbound
books.author: Robin Sloan
books.notes: A fresh new approach! I admire Robin's attempt at something decidedly new and fresh and form-breaking. The writing certainly kept me reading and I overall enjoyed it but it felt a little kitchen-sink-esque with maybe too many new ideas all at once? Also I think there's some core Arthurian analogy that I didn't quite make sense of... But overall an enjoyable read.

books.title: Guest Lecture
books.author: Martin Riker
books.notes: A weird little novel that I mostly enjoyed. I think the core message was supposed to land more aspirationally but the anxiety of the main character felt like it got in the way a bit too much?

books.title: Boys
books.author: Katie Hafner
books.notes: Read this on Eliot Peper's recommendation and loved it! A unique kind of setup and really nicely written. Kept me reading and engrossed. Recommended.

books.title: The Space Between Worlds
books.author: Micaiah Johnson
books.notes: Passable sci-fi with an interesting premise. The world was well crafted and the core mechanic was novel but the characters always felt a bit flat and the romance pretty far contrived!

books.title: The Invisible Life of Addie LaRue
books.author: V. E. Schwab
books.notes: A fast read, I enjoyed it in a kind of summer-beach-read kind of way. Had some fun moments.

books.title: The Steerswoman
books.author: Rosemary Kirstein
books.notes: I read this on recommendation from A Working Library and it didn't disappoint! Great writing and a unique world full of intrigue and more questions than answers...

books.title: The Stone Sky
books.author: N. K. Jemisin
books.notes: While I loved the series overall the third book really felt flat and didn't work for me. It's hard to put my finger on why but something really missed here...

books.title: The Obelisk Gate
books.author: N. K. Jemisin
books.notes: A great continuation of the series.

books.title: The Fifth Season
books.author: N. K. Jemisin
books.notes: Engaging rich descriptions - loved the underlying premise and the world that was built.

books.title: Spy Games
books.author: Adam Brookes
books.notes: Such pace! Loved the descriptions and characters.

books.title: Night heron
books.author: Adam Brookes
books.notes: Loved this! I don't read spy novels very often but Robin Sloan recommended it and I loved the story and the fast paced action. Fun change of pace - and there's some great writing in there. Recommended.

books.title: Mountain in the Sea
books.author: Ray Nayler
books.notes: Fun to read this against the backdrop of GPT3/GPT4! I enjoyed the book but found it kind of fizzled out at the end. I was hoping it was going to work towards some kind of crescendo but found the ending just kind of weak. But I still enjoyed the read.

books.title: Tomorrow, and Tomorrow, and Tomorrow
books.author: Gabrielle Zevin
books.notes: What a fun read! Poignant, fun and really engrossing. It reminded me of hints of Kavalier and Clay by Michael Chabon at times though I don't think it had quite the same depth. Recommended though!

books.title: Captains of the sands
books.author: Jorge Amado
books.notes: Love the style and sense of wonder that Jorge writes with. Perhaps I should read the other Bahia books in the series...

books.title: Suitcase Clone
books.author: Robin Sloan
books.notes: A lovely novella from Robin Sloan that builds on the Robin Sloan Cinematic Universe...! Fast pasted and full of intrigue. Definitely left me wanting more!

books.title: Popisho
books.author: Leone Ross
books.notes: What a magical lush book. Ugly, raw, squelchy. The opposite of the Ruth Ozeki book I just read... Popisho is full of exquisite descriptions, magical realism, surreal nonsense and raw, bloody, colorful magic. Full of gods and humans at their best and worst I absolutely loved this book. If you're looking for something that is a riot of color, emotion and humanity then this is it.

books.title: The Book of Form and Emptiness
books.author: Ruth Ozeki
books.notes: While at times Ruth Ozeki's writing is lyrical and magical, mostly this book felt kind of sterile. Neither of the main characters feel deeply explored and the most interesting characters (the aleph and the bottleman) are really only side events. Overall the book tasted like it had been aged in steel barrels and I was left wanting something more full bodied, more lyrical, more vivid.

books.title: Assassin's Fate
books.author: Robin Hobb
books.notes: Oof. That concludes reading all 16 of the realm of the elderlings books. I haven't kept detailed notes on them but I'm so glad that I read them all and read them in order. In many ways Nighteyes is the main character. These last three books tie together so many threads and loose ends - the storyline is dark but the ending is magical. Robin Hobb has such a powerful command of both small characters and giant worlds.

books.title: Fool's fate
books.author: Robin Hobb
books.notes: Are there stronger characters than the Fitz and the Fool? What depth of emotion. This series is a magical climax and feels like it rivals the original assassin trilogy! Loved reading this series.

books.title: The Golden Fool
books.author: Robin Hobb
books.notes: WHAT! So many mysteries unraveling, starting, crossing. Such emotionally charged scenes. Not giving anything away but this book is a big one.

books.title: Fool's Errand
books.author: Robin Hobb
books.notes: LOVE returning to Fitz and the Fool. I'm so deep in the Robin Hobb world now....

books.title: Ship of Destiny
books.author: Robin Hobb
books.notes: Wow! Another trilogy down. I love the callbacks and hints for the original series. Onwards!

books.title: The Mad Ship
books.author: Robin Hobb
books.notes: Now things are getting interesting! Love the origin story for the live ships - what an incredible dark backdrop to the whole saga.

books.title: Ship of Magic
books.author: Robin Hobb
books.notes: Onwards into the Robin Hobb cinematic universe! This series starts somewhat slowly but I love the all new (or is it!) version of live ships and their unique "magic".

books.title: Assassin's Quest
books.author: Robin Hobb
books.notes: I love this trilogy so much. This is my third or fourth full re-read since I was a teenager and it remains magical each time. Such world building, characters and adventure. Onwards to the remaining.... *checks notes*.... 14 books!

books.title: Royal Assassin
books.author: Robin Hobb
books.notes: That last line!! Such depth of characters. I really love this series. World building, unique ideas around magic, politics, love, wolves, assassins! Love it. Just as good as I remember.

books.title: Assassin's Apprentice
books.author: Robin Hobb
books.notes: Diving back into an epic read of the 17 Robin Hobb books. The farseer trilogy is my all time fave and I've read these books several times before but I'm starting here to read them all in order.

books.title: The mushroom at the end of the world
books.author: Anna Lowenhaupt Tsing
books.notes: A really magical exploration of global capitalism and... mushrooms?!

books.title: A Memory Called Empire
books.author: Arkady Martine
books.notes: What richness! The first time I've read sci-fi that felt a bit like Iain M Banks. Deep, complex, rich worlds with strong characters. An absolute treat - spanning langauge, poetry, politics, identity, memory and more. I cannot wait for the followup. After reading so much poorly written sci fi recently (Dune, The Ministry of the Future, Exhalation..) this was a refreshing breath of fresh air.

books.title: Laughter in the Dark
books.author: Vladamir Nabakov
books.notes: An airbnb read. Just lovely poetic writing - a breath of fresh air after a bunch of badly-written scifi.

books.title: The Ministry for the Future
books.author: Kim Stanley Robinson
books.notes: Abandoned during the free preview. Everyone is raving about this book but honestly the writing felt incredibly flat. I'm tired of sci-fi stories having bad writing :(

books.title: Exhalation
books.author: Ted Chiang
books.notes: Abandoned 2/3 of the way through :( - while I quite enjoyed some of the provocations in the stories ultimately the writing didn't captivate me. Left me feeling bored so I gave it up.

books.title: Multidimensional Executive Coaching
books.author: Ruth L. Orenstein
books.notes: Some great thought provoking ideas about coaching, consulting and being embedded inside organizations as an outsider. I especially love the concept in the book of overbounded or underbounded organizations.

books.title: The Player of Games
books.author: Iain M. Banks
books.notes: I have fond memories of the first time reading this and felt like it left a big impression on me. Re-reading this book I still loved it but the shine has come off a little - I think other culture books are perhaps better. Still, the world building (universe building!) that Iain M Banks does is like no other.

books.title: Dune
books.author: Frank Herbert
books.notes: Started reading this while traveling through Utah and Arizona to get a feel for desert living. I enjoyed the book but definitely didn't feel like it lived up to the hype. Inventive but the characters felt a little stale.

books.title: Working in Public: The Making and Maintenance of Open Source Software
books.author: Nadia Eghbal
books.notes: A great read about internet creators, economics of production, communities, influencers, open source and more. Nadia provides a ton of real data and examples but pairs them with big ideas and concepts. Essential read.

books.title: The Uncertainty Mindset
books.author: Vaughn Tan
books.notes: A wonderful rich book exploring the world of high end culinary R&D to find lessons applicable for other types of organizations. A really fun read - great stories about high end cooking as well as sharp insights about food.

books.title: Tomorrow Lies in Ambush
books.author: Bob Shaw
books.notes: Classic sci-fi short stories recommended by Matt Webb. Some really lovely ideas and great writing! All the stories are very character-driven and often reflect more strongly on the individual characters motives and identities over the larger sci-fi conceits! Lovely. Thanks Matt!

books.title: East of Eden
books.author: John Steinbeck
books.notes: What a magnificent - truly epic work. I'm a big Steinbeck fan already and I think I even read this one previously but loved immersing myself in this wonderful story. The biblical theme is almost too strong at times but is richly counterbalanced by Steinbeck's incredibly loving character portraits. Amazing.

books.title: Veil
books.author: Eliot Peper
books.notes: A really great fast-paced read. Eliot has a great knack for constructing plausible near-futures and then situating fully realized human stories within those futures. Thought provoking and enjoyable.

books.title: The Memory Police
books.author: Yoko Ogawa
books.notes: While the writing style at times is captivating - like a penny falling into a deep well - often the writing was unremarkable and the plot unfolded fairly slowly. All in the book was, ironically, forgettable. That said - the ending, where bodies start to fade away really resonated during this period of lockdown and isolation - it captures the essence of my embodied self fading away into an infinite series of zoom screens.

books.title: Working Identity- Unconventional Strategies for Reinventing Your Career
books.author: Herminia Ibarra
books.notes: A wonderful meditation on career change (and life change generally) as being a process of iterating and trying on new identities. Has deep implications for independents also. Going to blog this book up. Originally found via Vaughn Tan's newsletter.

books.title: An Introduction to Haiku
books.author: Harold Gould Henderson
books.notes: Brian suggested I get into Haiku and pick up this book and I'm glad I did! Beautiful, easy to read intro to Haiku. The author gives great context for what Haiku is, the main poets and how to read Haiku poetry. Recommended!

books.title: Tears of the Trufflepig
books.author: Fernando A. Flores
books.notes: A wonderful book. Like an absurdist Cormac McCarthy x Kurt Vonnegut mashup. Lyrical descriptions, wonderful characters and a wild imagination. Highly recommended.

books.title: A Winter‚Äôs Promise
books.author: Christelle Dabos
books.notes: There are moments when the lavish fantasy world and the magic contained in it sucked me in - but ultimately the character development and plot just didn't hang together to keep me reading. Good escapist reading but there are better fantasy worlds to lose yourself in than this one.

books.title: Less
books.author: Andrew Sean Greer
books.notes: A truly delightful novel - with hints of PG Wodehouse. This book really sucked me in with magical lush writing and a great wry tone. Definitely recommended.

books.title: Infinite Detail
books.author: Tim Maughan
books.notes: A fun quick read. There's some good language and some nice world-setting but I wish some of the characters had been more fully developed and I wish the central idea had been stronger. The ending kind of fizzles out and there could have been room for so much more here.. Good for a little lightweight-dytopia though.

books.title: Dead Astronauts
books.author: Jeff VanderMeer
books.notes: I think perhaps I made a mistake. I didn't realize until after I'd read it that it was part of the Borne series. Maybe that would have been useful because this book made zero sense. Like a William Burroughs book it was somehow interesting and riveting at times despite literally making no sense. Did I mention it makes no sense? The first section with the three astronauts was the most compelling..... Maybe I should read the other Borne books and it'll make more sense? But I doubt it.

books.title: The Nix
books.author: Nathan Hill
books.notes: Abandoned 500 pages in. I tried to keep going but just couldn't. A Very Bad Book. Highly un-recommended. This is a good takedown. So many characters are badly written sexually frustrated males and it's just all round a bad book. Couple sentences worth savoring but.. ugh.

books.title: A Gentleman in Moscow
books.author: Amor Towles
books.notes: Amor is a wonderful writer with so many lyrical touches, flourishes and turns of phrase. The feel of the book of politics, culture and acting in the proper way is great. Without posting spoilers there's a few themes in the book that make me feel like the book was written by a man - that some of the more emotionally rich moments are skipped over... But overall highly recommended as a fun, engaging and lyrical book.

books.title: Tempo - timing, tactics and strategy in narrative-driven decision-making
books.author: Venkatesh Rao
books.notes: I really should have read this years ago but I really enjoyed this piece. The core ideas around tempo of interactions, narrative time and that the kitchen is the best way to think about time will all stick with me for a while. Recommended.

books.title: Conversation -  How Talk Can Change Our Lives
books.author: Theodore Zeldin
books.notes: A delightful little book that was a gift from my friend Brian. A little meditation on conversations, how important they are and some of the explicit and implicit ways they can go wrong. At first I thought this was going to offer solutions and ideas but mostly it just offers poetry and provocations. I think it'll stick with me for a long time though - and the art from the author scattered through the book makes a lovely little object. Thanks Brian!

books.title: Recursion
books.author: Blake Crouch
books.notes: A fast-paced, high-action read. A fun time-travel romp with some great characters. Ultimately I thought the premise was smart and the writing handled it well but the whole novel felt a little shallow. There were some really meaty ideas about identity and family wrapped up here that kind of got sidelined for the sake of the technology-driven plot and I thought that was a shame. Fun read though.

books.title: Way Station
books.author: Clifford D. Simak
books.notes: Lovely vintage sci-fi recommended by Chris Butler. There's aliens, teleporting and... magic? But nothing flashy happens - it's an incredibly human story. This is a really thoughtful and fresh story. Highly recommended.

books.title: Idiots First
books.author: Bernard Malamud
books.notes: The opening line of Idiot's First is a masterpiece. 'The thin ticking of the tin clock stopped'. Loved a few of the other stories but some were definitely forgettable. I'd recommend dipping your toe in and at the very least reading the title story Idiots First.

books.title: The Scar
books.author: China Mi√©ville
books.notes: Ah what delicious sludgy, dark, human texture. China Mi√©ville's descriptive language and world building is unparalleled. This is book two (after reading Perdido Street Station last year). These books are long and luxurious so perhaps not the best entry point if you're new to his writing but if you like this kind of thing there's nothing better. My only quarrel with this book was the ending... It felt somewhat unsatisfying, or rather unfinished - where a typical book resolves this felt like the open sea was still in front of you? But it's a very minor comment as mostly the strength of this book was that every page told a lifetime of texture. Definitely going to read book three of this trilogy after a break.

books.title: Last Night
books.author: James Salter
books.notes: After reading All That Is I had to wash my palette and get back to some of his delicious writing. This was much more in line with Light Years and contained some lovely moments. None of the short stories will linger with me too long but it's a short read and I'd recommend it.

books.title: Emissaries Guide to Worlding
books.author: Ian Cheng
books.notes: The core idea of the masks - the cartoonist, the director, the hacker and the emissary - is wonderful and a new lens to look at the world through, so overall I'd recommend the book. But there was also an incredible over-indulgence from the author to live inside his own worlds (which feels very finite game like, not infinite game like). And the lack of people anywhere in his worlds is also problematic. That said - the book as an object is beautiful and wonderfully designed.

books.title: The Prisoner
books.author: Thomas M. Disch
books.notes: I really enjoyed this - a delightfully British story of being trapped, like a combination of Kafka and PG Wodehouse. The plot derailed itself in a few places and there was a whole Shakespere reference that kind of went over my head but the writing was wonderful. Recommended.

books.title: Oval
books.author: Elvia Wilk
books.notes: I really loved this. Distinctive, fresh writing that captures so much of the present weirdness in society while also somehow feeling timeless. The middle third dragged slightly for me but the descent into ecological weird towards the end is just wonderful and reminds me of the Annihiliation series by Jeff Vandermeer. Oh and the whole book centers on this premise of artists becoming 'consultants' which is magnificent. Recommended. Verdict- üëçüå≤

books.title: All That Is
books.author: James Salter
books.notes: A wildly disappointing read. Not that it was so bad but that having recently read Light Years I was expecting so much more. There were moments of brilliance in the writing and some of the scenes will linger with me overall the book didn't really make me feel anything. Definitely read Light Years instead.

books.title: Borderless
books.author: Eliot Peper
books.notes: Book two of the Analog series. Overall I connected less with the main character in this one but connected more with the overall premise which is very thought provoking. It feels today that we are actively living through the end (or at least a phase transition) of sovereignty. Compelling and a quick read.

books.title: Bandwidth
books.author: Eliot Peper
books.notes: I completely devoured this book. The characters and pace keeps it flowing but the ideas will stick with me - it's grounded in a very near future and the concepts are well thought through. Excited to keep diving into Borderless next.

books.title: The Gone Away World
books.author: Nick Harkaway
books.notes: A majestic feat of imagination - whirlwind story of a gong-fu epic in a world gone mad. Definitely feels like it needed better editing or structuring and was about 100 pages too long but the strength of imagination and grasp of poetry really captivated me. Picked this up off the street on the way home from kung-fu training (approriate!). I'll be reading more of his work.

books.title: Light Years
books.author: James Salter
books.notes: This book completely destroyed me. The writing is dense and poetic like almost no one I've ever read. Did you know glass is a liquid and slowly 'flows'? This book operates on a time horizon and 'flows' through lives in a deeply transformative way. Found via Phil Gyford

books.title: Delirious New York
books.author: Rem Koolaas
books.notes: It's architecture writing but lyrical, magical and opinionated. A tour de force through New York's history with tons of interesting characters, ideas, explorations and more. Ideas include congestion as an organizing principle of the city, and every block being an archipelago. Wonderful and highly recommended.

books.title: Tomorrow In The Battle Think On Me
books.author: Javier Marias
books.notes: Abandoned. I think somewhere in this book is buried a wonderful treasure. The looping self-aware story is fundamentally interesting and new but the language that wraps around it chokes it to death. Abandoned about half way through.

books.title: Summerland
books.author: Hannu Rajaniemi
books.notes: A wonderful original work - full of interesting characters. Ghosts! Spys! Old London! Really enjoyed this and tore through it super fast.

books.title: Finite & Infinite Games
books.author: James Carse
books.notes: Great unique book, wonderful analogy to finite and infinite writing....

books.title: The Power
books.author: Naomi Alderman
books.notes: Provocative premise but I felt it squandered an opportunity at a deeper political and/or emotional exploration of what would happen if teenage girls gained a new incredible power. Somehow it resorted to.... fucking and fighting?

books.title: Perdido Street Station
books.author: China Mieville
books.notes: A staggering, creative, filthy, engrossing tour through a world with such magical and rich depths. No one can build worlds like China.

books.title: Satin Island
books.author: Tom McCarthy
books.notes: William Gibson meets Kafka. A corporate strategy consultant / ethnographer ponders the meaning of life and searches for the Great Report.

books.title: The Dark Dark
books.author: Samantha Hunt
books.notes: Tender, oozing, lyrical, dark, DARK stories of being human. Did I mention they are dark? What writing though! What imagination!

books.title: Pattern Recognition
books.author: William Gibson
books.notes: The consultant allergic to brands. Marketing agencies that wield global influence over culture.

books.title: Satin Island
books.author: Tom McCarthy
books.notes: Then the Great Report would not be something that was either to-come or completed, in-the-past: it would be all now. Present-tense anthropology; anthropology as way-of-life. That was it: Present-Tense Anthropology‚Ñ¢; an anthropology that bathed in presence, and in nowness‚Äîbathed in it as in a deep, bubbling and nymph-saturated well. And yet ‚Ä¶ And yet ‚Ä¶ And yet. The Great Report still had to be composed. That was the deal: with Peyman, with the age. Even if it wasn‚Äôt composed in a way that conformed to any previous anthropological model, it nonetheless had, somehow, to find a form. It was all a question of form. What fluid, morphing hybrid could I come up with to be equal to that task? What medium, or media, would it inhabit? Would it tell a story? If so, how, and about what, or whom? If not, how would it all congeal, around what cohere? How could I elevate the photos I had pinned about my walls, the sketches, doodles, musings, all the stuff cached on my hard-drive, the audio-files and diaries not my own‚Äîhow could I elevate all these from secondary sources to be quantified, sucked dry, then cast away, to primary players in this story, or non-story? Above and beyond this, how could life as lived become transmogrified from field-work into work, the Work?

books.title: The Sleep Consultant
books.author: Robin Sloan
books.notes: A one-off print run zine fiction from Robin Sloan. The corporate sleep consultant asleep for 5 years. Now online!

books.title: The Art of Gig
books.author: Venkatesh Rao
books.notes: A wonderful madcap dash through an engagement as an indie consultant deploying Structured Conversation Operations and encountering McKinsey (who come in like a SWAT team). Love it. Read it here.

books.title: A Mathematician's Apology
books.author: G. H. Hardy
books.notes: A haunting look at a retiring mathematician who knows he is past his prime. For those who have never experienced advanced maths this is a wonderful short book that hints at the poetry and beauty involved.

books.title: Fermat's Last Theorum
books.author: Simon Singh
books.notes: This is what rockstar maths looks like - being lonely and scared for 10 years followed by depression and then immortality. The story of how one of the most famous problems ever was solved by a single genius. Fascinating reading. Made me cry.

books.title: G√∂del, Escher, Bach
books.author: Douglas R. Hofstadter
books.notes: This book is sort of about Godel's incompleteness theorem. It also changed my life. I'm not kidding! Technically challenging for most non-maths people I think but still accessible with work. Did I mention it changed my life?

books.title: Logicomix
books.author: Apostolos Doxiadis
books.notes: If there was ever a maths superhero, Bertrand Russell might be right up there. This comic is funny, moving, emotional and accessible. Everyone should read this, regardless of how much you like maths.

books.title: Uncle Petros and Goldbach's Conjecture
books.author: Apostolos Doxiadis
books.notes: A novel by the same guy behind Logicomix. This is a bit more mathsy but also a cracking story. More about sense of purpose, redemption and the quest for knowledge than it is about maths.

books.title: Flatland
books.author: Edwin A Abbott
books.notes: A delightful little story about a two dimensional object wrestling with the concept of three dimensions. Poetic.
